entries.name: Abishais
entries: 每个abishai都曾经是一个凡人，在死前以某种方式赢得了提亚马特的青睐，作为奖励，发现自己的灵魂变成了一个龙魔，在九层地狱为她服务。每种阿比斯海都与提亚马特的五个龙头之一有关：黑、蓝、绿、红和白。
提亚马特部署阿比莎斯作为她的代理人，派他们去代表她在地狱和整个多元宇宙的利益。有些人的任务很简单，比如向邪教分子传递信息。其他的则有更大的责任，如领导大型团体、暗杀目标和在军队中服役。在所有情况下，阿比沙斯都对提亚马特狂热忠诚，准备在必要时牺牲自己的生命。
Abishais站在九层地狱的正常等级之外，有自己的指挥系统，并最终向提亚马特（和阿斯莫德，当他选择使用他们时）负责。其他大恶魔可以命令阿比莎为他们工作，但大多数大恶魔很少这样做，因为永远不清楚阿比莎是听从提亚马特的命令还是阿斯莫德的命令。违背提亚马特的命令有内在的风险，但干扰阿斯莫德的计划则会招致一定的破坏。
堕落者擅长于创造保护性的魔法护盾。君主、贵族和其他富有的人通常都会雇佣堕落者来提供保护。
一个{@creature young kruthik|MPMM}需要六个月的稳定进食才能达到成年体型。成年克鲁斯克的自然寿命大约为7年。
成年kruthiks的腿上长有尖锐的突起，可以将这些匕首大小的尖刺甩向爪子够不到的敌人。
年长的大蛇，被称为成年人和长者，已经吃了很多记忆，它们可以用身体的物质形成它们所吞噬的生物的复制品，把这些复制品送去引诱猎物进入它们的魔掌，同时用长长的粘液卷轴把它们拴在粘液中。这些复制的生物除了有一股淡淡的硫磺味外，与它们的受害者没有区别。Oblexes利用这些复制体将猎物引向危险，或者潜入定居点，以便它们能以高级受害者为食。

monsterFluff.name: Alhoon

entries: 有很多理由要避免走巫师的路。一个无常的解决方案是自相矛盾的。以阿尔霍恩为例。它们需要灵魂来保持不萎缩。我看不出有什么吸引力。
追求奥术魔法的心灵传播者被当作异类放逐，对他们来说，不可能与长者的大脑进行永恒的交流。通往巫术王国的道路提供了另一种逃避死亡永恒的方式，但这条道路很漫长，而且充满了障碍。Alhoons是使用捷径来达到巫师状态的心灵传播者。

长老们的大脑禁止心灵传播者追求除幻术以外的魔法力量，但这并不是他们必须经常执行的禁令。伊利特人除了自己的同类外，不接受任何主人，所以向任何神或其他世界的守护者低头并不是他们的天性。然而，巫术仍然是一种诱惑。在法术书的书页中，伊里特人看到了一个获得权威的系统。通过撰写这本书的巫师的著作，illithid人看到了一个高度智慧的头脑的运作。大多数发现咒语书的幻术师的反应是憎恶或漠不关心，但对某些人来说，咒语书是通往新思维方式的大门。

在一段时间内，对这种禁忌文本的研究可以瞒过其他illithids，甚至瞒过长老的大脑。然而，最终，决心追求巫术的掠心者必须为了自己的安全逃离殖民地。一旦他们尝到了离开殖民地的自由，有些人就会珍惜自己的隐私，有些人则寻求与类似的思想交流，还有一些人则试图通过提升自己的地位来支配一个殖民地，而这种领导地位通常是由一个长老的大脑来担任的。无论如何，所有这样的奥术师都面临着同样严峻的事实：当他们死亡时，他们不会加入长老大脑中的心智群体--异端心智永远不会被接受为集体的一部分。对他们来说，死亡意味着遗忘。
Lichdom提供了救赎和可以无限期追求知识的前景。然而，学习实现lichdom的秘密需要一个奥术施法者达到力量的顶点--鉴于可用的导师和培训的稀缺性，这对心灵传播者来说是一个重大挑战。
面对这一现实，一群由九名心灵传播者组成的奥术师用他们的奥术魔法和幻术编织了一个新的真理。这九个人自称为 "Alhoon"，那些追随他们脚步的人也被称为同名。

entries.name: Collaborative Undeath
entries: 要想成为Alhoons，心灵传播者奥术师必须合作创造一个心灵陷阱的periapt，一个用银、绿宝石和紫水晶制成的拳头大小的容器。这个过程需要至少3个心灵传播者奥术师，并在为期3天的法术和灵能交流仪式中牺牲同等数量的活体受害者的灵魂。仪式完成后，自由意志的死亡被赋予了思想絮乱者，使他们变成了阿尔霍恩。
起初，alhoon很难与普通读心者区分开来。最明显的区别是，它没有一个念力使用者永远存在的粘液涂层。没有这种保护，alhoon的皮肤会变得干燥和开裂，它的眼睛可能会显得干瘪和凹陷。这两个线索都很容易被没有见过噬心者的人错过。然而，在很短的时间内，alhoon的肉体就会枯萎，其空洞的眼窝会像其他地衣一样闪耀着冰冷的针尖之光。
与真正的巫师法器不同的是，思维陷阱的periapt在被摧毁后并不能使alhoons恢复到不死状态。相反，被摧毁的alhoon的思想会被转移到periapt中，在那里它与任何其他被困住的alhoon思想以及被牺牲者的灵魂保持交流。
心灵诱捕术所赋予的不死之身只持续到所选择的活体受害者的生命。因此，牺牲了一个200岁的精灵的alhoon期待着比牺牲了一个35岁的人更长久的存在。Alhoons可以通过与新的受害者重复这个仪式来延长他们的存在，有效地为自己重新设置时钟。

破坏思维陷阱的periapt会使被困在里面的人被遗忘，因此alhoons经常一起工作，为他们的periapt和他们喜欢的仪式地点创造精心的保护措施。有时，一个alhoon被委托保管思维陷阱的periapt，但这是一个危险的提议。任何持有periapt的人都会在攻击、蓄力和检查中对与之相关的alhoons产生优势，而这些alhoons反过来在攻击、蓄力和检查中对持有者也会产生不利。此外，持有者可以与被困在其中的任何牺牲的灵魂进行心灵感应，periapt中的alhoons也可以与持有者进行心灵感应。携带periapt的生物不能阻止alhoons的交流，但可以让被困的灵魂安静下来。

monsterFluff.name: Alkilith
entries: 铝石很容易被误认为是某种出现在门口、窗户和其他入口处的恶臭真菌。这些滴落的侵染物掩盖了alkilith的恶魔本质，使本应是一个可怕的警告显得很奇怪，但在其他方面是无害的。无论烷烃在哪里扎根，它们都会削弱现实的结构，创造出一个门户，让更多邪恶的恶魔通过它入侵。
白石的出现预示着一个巨大的错误和一场即将到来的灾难。白化石会寻找一个可以扎根的孔隙，如窗户或门，在孔隙周围伸展它的身体，用粘性分泌物固定自己。如果不受干扰，这个开口就会与深渊相适应，并最终成为通往那个位面的传送门（参见《地下城主指南》中的 "位面传送门"）。
阿尔基里斯是从尤布勒克斯那可怕的、令人颤抖的身体上脱落的碎片中产生的。它们逐渐有了自我意识，并试图找到进入物质世界的途径。由于大多数崇拜者认为召唤他们太过危险--毕竟他们可以创造出通往深渊的门户--因此，阿尔基里斯必须找到其他的逃亡路线，离开他们的本位面。

monsterFluff.name: Allip
entries: 当一个生物发现一个强大的生命用强大的诅咒来保护的秘密时，其结果往往是创造一个Allip。以这种方式保护的秘密范围很广，从恶魔领主的真名到宇宙秩序的隐藏真相。这个生物获得了这个秘密，但诅咒消灭了它的身体，留下了一个由受害者的心灵碎片和压倒性的精神痛苦组成的幽灵。

每一个阿利普都被一种可怕的洞察力所困扰，这种洞察力折磨着它仅存的思想。在其他生物面前，Allip试图通过分享它的秘密来减轻这种负担。该生物只能传授给它一个注定要失败的知识碎片，但这碎片足以让接受者遭受暂时的精神痛苦和暴力强迫症的折磨。被Allip攻击的幸存者有时会被强迫去了解更多关于这个怪物产生的原因。奇怪的短语在他们的脑海中回荡，奇怪的幻觉占据了他们的梦境。一些巨大的真相就在他们的记忆之外，这种感觉困扰着他们几天、几个月，有时甚至几年之后，他们的命运遭遇。

entries.name: Insidious Lore
entries: 阿利普可能会试图分享它的传说，以摆脱它的诅咒并进入来世。它可以通过引导另一个生物写下它所知道的东西，来转移它头脑中的知识。这个过程需要几天或可能几周。Allip可以通过潜伏在学者的书房或工作场所来完成这项任务。如果Allip保持隐藏，它的受害者会逐渐被疯狂的能量所征服。一个学者在突然的洞察力的驱使下，夜以继日地工作，产生了成堆的文字，但几乎不记得文件到底包含什么。如果Allip成功了，它就会从这个世界上消失--它的可怕的秘密隐藏在学者的文本中的某个地方，等待着被它的下一个受害者发现。

monsterFluff.name: Amnizu
entries: 阿姆尼祖斯（Amnizus）带领地狱军团作战，并在通往地狱的入口处指挥守护者。阿姆尼兹人傲慢、好欺负、无情，但他们也是高度聪明的战术家，并且永远忠诚，这是地狱大公们所看重的品质。
一些阿姆尼兹人在冥河两岸的堡垒中执行监视冥河的重要任务，冥河在那里流经迪斯和斯蒂吉亚。他们收集以（%0%）形式到达的灵魂。Lemures没有个性或记忆；他们只被邪恶的欲望所驱使。在这里巡逻的阿米兹人将九层地狱的规则灌输到新来者的脑海中，并将他们召集成军团。
依靠暴力来维持他们的存在，愤怒的悲鸣者--有时被称为愤怒者--在他们的敌人反击时变得更加强大。不过，如果一个生物选择不攻击，这种悲鸣者就会变得混乱，其攻击也会减弱。它也有两个头，彼此不停地争吵着。

monsterFluff.name: Annis Hag
entries: 安尼斯女巫的巢穴在山区或丘陵。这些驼背和驼肩的女巫是他们中最大的，也是身体最强壮的，身高8英尺。它们可以轻易地将一个完全成年的人撕碎，但它们喜欢猎杀年轻人，更喜欢他们的肉体。
Annis hag在森林边缘和其他他们声称会引起附近村庄和定居点的恐惧和不信任的地区留下了他们残忍的标志物。对Annis hag来说，没有什么比让一个曾经充满活力的社区因恐惧而瘫痪更让人高兴的了，所以人们从不在晚上冒险，陌生人会受到怀疑和愤怒，而父母则警告他们的孩子。"要听话，否则Annis会抓住你。
当Annis感到特别残忍时，女巫就会采用慈祥的长者的外表，在一个偏远的地方接近一个孩子，并给他们一个铁信物（如下所述），通过这个信物，孩子可以神奇地向女巫倾诉。随着时间的推移，"奶奶 "或 "爷爷 "让孩子相信做坏事是可以的--从打碎东西或未经允许到处游荡开始，然后发展到把人推下楼梯或放火烧房子。最终，孩子惊恐的家庭和社区面临着痛苦的决定，即如何处理这个看似无情的孩子。
就像女巫为了腐蚀孩子而与他们交好一样，他们可能会收养一群食人魔、巨魔或其他生物（（%0%）和（%1%）），通过蛮力、侮辱和迷信统治他们。

entries.name: Iron Token
entries: 一个Annis hag可以拔出他们的一颗铁牙或指甲，并花1分钟将其塑造和打磨成硬币、戒指或小镜子的形式。
此后，任何持有此铁质令牌的生物都可以与女巫进行低声交谈，前提是该生物和女巫的距离在10英里以内。当女巫通过令牌说话时，持有者可以听到女巫的低语，但听不到女巫所在地的任何其他声音。同样地，女巫可以听到令牌持有人的声音，但不能听到周围的噪音。
一个巫婆在同一时间最多可以有三个铁质令牌处于活动状态。作为一个行动，女巫可以辨别方向和与这些激活的令牌的大致距离。巫婆可以在任何距离停用其中的任何一个令牌（无需行动），这时令牌会保留其当前的形式，但失去其魔力。
学徒是为更有经验的巫师服务或上学的新手奥术施法者。他们做一些琐碎的工作，如烹饪或清洁，以换取魔法方面的教育。

monsterFluff.name: Archdruid
entries: 大德鲁伊守护着他们领域的自然奇迹。他们很少与远离德鲁伊丛林和神殿的人们交流，除非对自然秩序或附近的社区有很大的威胁。一个大德鲁伊通常有一个或多个学生，他们是（%0%），大德鲁伊的巢穴通常由忠诚的野兽和费伊生物守护。
当大德鲁伊使用他们的改变形状行动时，你可以选择他们变成的生物，并遵守行动的限制。或者你可以在大德鲁伊喜爱的形状表上滚动，以决定大德鲁伊采用的形态。

monsterFluff.name: Archer
entries: 弓箭手保卫城堡，在文明的边缘猎取野味，在军事单位中充当炮兵，偶尔也会作为强盗或商队守卫赚些钱。
一些著名的弓箭手和弓箭手团体以他们箭上的特殊弹片而闻名。你可以在弓箭手投掷表上滚动，以确定个别弓箭手或他们的团体所使用的独特的投掷物。

entries.caption: Archer Fletching
rows: 猫头鹰熊的鬃毛上的羽毛

monsterFluff.name: Armanite
entries: 成群结队的亚曼人在深渊的废墟上奔跑，一心想着屠杀和死亡，被无节制的嗜血所驱使。无论它们是被更强大的恶魔控制，还是为了战斗而冲锋陷阵，阿曼人都会用它们的爪子和蹄子，以及它们长长的鞭子般的尾巴来撕碎敌人。
在恶魔领主的军队中，阿曼人扮演着重装骑兵的角色，带头冲锋陷阵，撕开敌人的侧翼。阿曼尼特人一直在战斗，甚至在找不到其他敌人的情况下也会互相争斗。他们是理想的冲击部队，完全无情，大胆到愚蠢的程度。
使得阿曼人如此可怕的部分原因是他们所掌握的武器的数量。它们拥有密集的蹄子，以卷曲的爪子为末端的爪子，以及长长的尾巴，其锯齿状的脊柱可以剥去受害者的肉，它们用这些来刻画它们的敌人。当它们遇到强硬的阵型时，它们可以调用它们与生俱来的魔法，释放出闪电，在敌人的队伍中炸出一个个洞。

monsterFluff.name: Astral Dreadnought
entries: 巨大而可怕的星际无畏战舰在星界的银色虚空中出没，让平面旅行者一想到它们就会不寒而栗。自多元宇宙诞生以来，无畏舰一直在星界迷雾中滑行，试图吞噬它们遇到的所有其他生物。
无畏者从头到尾都覆盖着一层层厚厚的、带刺的板子，它有两条虬结的四肢，末端是经过魔法强化的钳爪。星座似乎在它的单眼深处旋转，而它的蛇形尾巴则拖向银色的虚空。它吞下的任何东西都沉积在一个独特的半平面中--一个封闭的空间，其中包含了价值数个世纪的残渣，以及旅行者的遗体。这个地方有重力和可呼吸的空气，有机物质会在那里腐烂。当无畏战舰死亡时，它的半位面就会消失，其内容被释放到星界。
Aurochs是一种大型、凶猛的牛，有突出的犄角。在许多地方，成群的牛自由自在地游荡，而在其他地方，兽人和人类从小就训练它们，让它们带着骑手参加战斗。
艾拉德林经常在进入秋季的时候被善意的感觉所征服。在这方面，他们化解冲突，并通过使用他们的魔法来缓解困扰前来寻求援助的人们的任何疾病，从而减轻痛苦。他们不容忍在他们面前出现暴力，并迅速采取行动解决争端，以确保和平的继续统治。

monsterFluff.name: Babau

entries: 我对大多数孩子没有印象。他们是他们祖先的混合体，但往往更让人失望。你会认为下层世界中两个最美丽、最嗜血的生命会创造出一个更有潜力的生物。相反，这个可怕的巴博未能与它父母的恶魔般的辉煌相提并论。
恶魔和魔鬼为了争夺下层世界的控制权而无休止地发生冲突。其中一场战斗是大恶魔格拉西亚的军团与恶魔领主格拉兹兹特的尖叫群对抗。据说当格拉西亚用她的剑打伤格拉兹兹特时，他的血落在地上就出现了第一批巴巴斯。他们的突然出现帮助击溃了格拉西亚，并确保了格拉兹兹特作为深渊中最杰出的恶魔领主之一的地位。
巴鲍尔恶魔具有魔鬼的狡猾和恶魔的嗜血性。它有皮革般的皮肤，紧紧地包裹着它憔悴的身躯，从它修长的头骨后面伸出一个弯曲的角。巴巴乌可怕的目光可以削弱一个生物，它的爪子闪烁着酸性粘液的光芒。

monsterFluff.name: Bael
entries: 魔鬼和恶魔之间的血战已经持续了数个世纪，而且没有结束的迹象，雄心勃勃的大恶魔们有很多机会在持续的斗争中赢得名声、荣耀和权力。巴尔公爵，玛门最重要的附庸之一，因其胜利而赢得了名声和赞誉。贝尔负责领导66个{@creature barbed devil||barbed devils}的连队，事实证明他是一个战术天才，在一次又一次战胜深渊主人的过程中，为自己和主人赢得了尊重。玛门依靠贝尔来保护他的财产，因为贝尔的战斗力很强。在许多其他大恶魔失去地位的时候，玛门从来没有被赶走过，这证明了贝尔在战场上的技巧。
由于他的成就，贝尔被授予青铜将军的称号。尽管他获得了荣誉，但他在地狱政治的泥潭中艰难跋涉。他的批评者称他为天真，尽管从未当面说过。他的主要兴趣一直是在战斗中领导士兵，所以他发现自己升到更高等级的野心不断受到政治上精明的对手的阻挠，这让他感到沮丧。
贝尔更喜欢让他的对手成为仆人，而被束缚在他手下的凡人则通过成为他高超计谋的牺牲品来获得他们的悲惨地位。贝尔很乐意饶恕那些被他打败的人的生命--如果他们向他保证他们的灵魂和服务。恶魔是个例外；尽管他愿意腐蚀几乎所有其他的敌人，但他总是摧毁被他打败的恶魔。
贝尔也欢迎凡人为他服务，如果他们能在政治上为他提供优势。他招募精明的人，并依靠他们在玛门的法庭上代表他的利益，这样他就可以自由地追求他的战斗欲望。
尽管他对战斗以外的事务缺乏兴趣，或者也许正因为如此，贝尔获得了一小批崇拜者的追随。那些在他的祭坛前膜拜的人称他为 "地狱之王"，而最痴心妄想的人认为他是所有魔鬼的主宰。在奥术界，某些著作，如可怕的《火之书》，说贝尔向世界揭示了隐形咒语，尽管一些魔法学者激烈地驳斥了这种说法。贝尔有时被描绘成一只蟾蜍、一只猫、一个人，或这些形式的某种组合。

monsterFluff.name: Balhannoth
entries: 原产于暗影城，邪恶的、掠夺性的巴尔汉诺斯改变了它巢穴中的现实，使这个地方看起来对旅行者很有吸引力。一种有限的心灵感应使巴尔汉诺斯能够识别其猎物期望得到满足的地方的图像，如旅馆或提供治疗的寺庙。然后它就会扭曲自己周围的现实，隐藏自己并重塑自己的环境，使之与这样的地方相似。这种模仿是不完美的，但它足以欺骗贪婪或绝望的生物。一旦它的猎物进入陷阱，它就会抓住目标并传送走，以他们的恐惧和绝望为食。
地牢建造者和地下城暴君有时会冒险进入暗影城，捕捉巴尔汉诺斯作为守护者使用。

entries.name: A Balhannoth's Lair
entries: 在Shadowfell，balhannoths把它们的巢穴建在它们猎杀的生物所居住的地方附近。它们通常在人迹罕至的道路上出没，抢夺走来的人。在暗黑世界中作为守护者的巴尔汉诺斯可能会在暗黑世界通道附近的洞穴中筑巢，并守护着进出其守护者的飞地的道路。

monsterFluff.name: Banderhobb
entries: Banderhobb是影子和肉体的混合体。通过卑鄙的魔法，这些成分呈现出一种巨大而可怕的直立形状，类似于双足的蟾蜍。在这种形态下，班德霍布会暂时为它的创造者服务，成为一个暴徒、小偷和绑架者，吞噬不小心的人。
女巫们设计了一种制造班德霍布的仪式--知道这种仪式的女巫可能愿意以合适的价格来传授它。其他一些邪恶的费伊人和强大的火人也知道这个过程，还有一些凡人法师也知道。
在其短暂的存在期间，Banderhobb试图执行其创造者的命令。它在完成自己的任务时，并不关心它所遭受或造成的伤害。它唯一的愿望是服务和成功。被指派追踪目标的Banderhobb在得到一绺头发、个人物品或其他与目标有关的物品时特别危险。拥有这样的物品可以让它在一英里外感知生物的位置。
一个Banderhobb履行其职责，直到其存在结束。当它过期时，通常是在它出生后的几天，它只留下了焦油状的粘液和一缕阴影。传说中，在阴影地带有一座不祥的塔，那里的阴影有时会发生变化，班德霍布会在那里游荡。

monsterFluff.name: Baphomet
entries: 在巴弗灭的信条中，文明是弱点，残暴是力量，他是有角的国王和野兽的王子。他被那些想打破文明的束缚、释放兽性的人所崇拜，因为巴弗灭设想了一个没有约束的世界，在那里，生物们可以实现他们最嗜血的欲望。
献给巴弗灭的邪教使用迷宫和复杂的绳结作为他们的标志。他们创造秘密场所来放纵自己，包括他们的主人喜欢的那种迷宫。沾满鲜血的冠冕以及铁和铜的武器装饰着他们虔诚的祭坛。
随着时间的推移，一个{@cult cult of baphomet|mpmm|cultist of Baphomet}会被他的影响所玷污，获得血色的眼睛和粗糙的、变厚的头发。小角最终从崇拜者的额头上长出来。随着时间的推移，一个虔诚的崇拜者可能会完全变成一个牛头人，这被认为是野兽王子最大的礼物。
巴弗灭出现时是一个可怕的、20英尺高的牛头人，有六个铁角。他的红色眼睛里燃烧着恶魔般的光芒。虽然他充满了兽性的血腥欲望，但在他的内心深处有一个残酷而狡猾的智慧，致力于颠覆所有的文明。
巴弗灭挥舞着一把名为 "裂心 "的巨大利刃。他也会向他的敌人发起冲锋，用他的角来刺穿他们，把他的敌人踩进土里，像野兽一样用牙齿撕碎他们。

entries.name: Cultists of Baphomet
entries: {@note See the {@cult Cult of Baphomet|MPMM}条目。}

entries.name: Baphomet's Lair
entries: 巴弗灭的巢穴是他的宫殿，Lyktion，它位于被称为无尽迷宫的深渊层上。Lyktion坐落在平面迷宫的曲折通道中，被维护得一尘不染，周围有一条护城河，以三维迷宫的方式建造。这座宫殿是一个高耸的结构，其内部就像它所处的平面一样是一个迷宫；里面住着（%0%）、（%1%）和（%2%）。

monsterFluff.name: Bard
entries: 吟游诗人是有天赋的诗人，讲故事的人，以及游历四方的艺人。他们通常出现在酒馆里，或者与快乐的冒险家队伍、粗犷的雇佣兵和富有的赞助人在一起。
每个吟游诗人都是至少一种表演类型的大师。你可以选择一个吟游诗人的主要类型，或者你可以在吟游诗人（%0%）类型表上滚动来确定它。

monsterFluff.name: Barghest
entries: 很久以前，神Maglubiyet--征服者，然后是早期地精的领主--与Gehenna将军讨价还价，寻求援助。将军提供了尤格罗特，然后这些尤格罗特为马格鲁比耶特服务而死亡。然而，当履行他的契约的时候，马格鲁比耶特违背了协议。为了报复，地府将军创造了噬魂兽来吞噬地精的灵魂。
每一个巴格斯特的任务，都是由地府将军植入的，就是吞噬灵魂。它通过吞噬被它杀死的人的身体来吞噬这些灵魂，更喜欢地精族。
Barghest渴望有一天能完成它的任务，回到地府，并直接在他的yugoloth军团中为将军服务，但它不会不分青红皂白地杀害地精。通过吞噬哥布林人首领和其他有权势的人的灵魂，巴格斯特在来世赢得了更高的地位。Barghests通常对自己的真实本性保密，在有机会的时候捕食偶尔的孤独的地精，直到他们长大成人，有能力寻找更强大的猎物。Barghest避免接触大型的明火。
任何大于其身体的火焰都会成为通往地府的通道，并将其放逐到那个位面，在那里它很可能会因为失败而被杀或被尤格罗人奴役。

monsterFluff.name: Berbalang
entries: Berbalangs匍匐在漂浮在星界上的死去的神灵的（%0%）遗体上。他们痴迷于收集秘密，包括从他们居住的神灵和死去的生物的骨头中收集秘密，他们召唤出死者的灵魂，强迫他们说出他们生前所学的东西。
Berbalangs喜欢只和死物说话，特别是只和他们召唤出来的灵魂说话，希望能学到秘密。他们把自己的故事记录在曾经属于这些生物的骨头上，从而保存了他们获得的信息。

追求知识是Berbalangs做任何事情的动力。虽然他们主要是从死人身上学习他们的秘密，但他们也不忘监视活人，从他们身上获取知识。Berbalang可以创造一个自己的幽灵复制体，并派这个复制体通过观察神和他们的仆人聚集的地方来收集其他星球的信息。当Berbalang通过它的复制体感知环境时，它的实际身体是（%0%），不能保护自己。因此，Berbalang通常只在很短的时间内使用它的复制体，然后再将意识返回到它的身体。
Berbalangs所积累的知识使他们成为旅行在各星球上的强者的重要信息来源。然而，Berbalangs不理会请愿者，除非他们带着一个重要的秘密或一个特别有趣的生物的骨头来。一些Githyanki已经能够与这些生物达成交易，利用Berbalangs监视他们的敌人，并看管他们在物质世界的小窝。

monsterFluff.name: Bheur Hag
entries: Bheur hags生活在寒冷的土地上，偏爱雪山。这些女巫在冬季变得更加活跃，利用她们的冰雪和天气魔法让附近的居民生活得很痛苦。
巫婆的皮肤呈蓝色，就像一个被冻死的人。女巫的头发是白色的，女巫很憔悴，苍白的眼睛被青色的肉所包围。布尔哈格携带一根扭曲的灰色木杖，可以像飞天扫帚一样骑在上面，可以增强哈格的魔法。
Bheur hag被致命的寒冷所激发的自私行为所吸引，比如为了一件冬衣而谋杀一个旅行者，或者为了木柴而砍伐干尸的小树林。如果这些行为是无缘无故的，比如一个贪婪的商人为了过冬而囤积多余的食物，而其他人却在挨饿，那么这些行为对Bheur来说就特别甜蜜。Bheurs利用他们操纵天气的能力，用严寒来打击村庄，希望灌输一种绝望的情绪，让人们互相对立。
在战斗中，女巫也会努力激发恐怖感。当靠近一个最近被杀的敌人时，巫婆可能会放弃攻击，以尸体为食。这种屠杀的景象足以让大多数证人感到恐惧。
黑衣人是刺客和潜入者的专家，他们可以编织阴影来掩盖他们的存在，使他们能够到达一个可以对目标进行致命一击的地方。

monsterFluff.name: Blackguard
entries: 黑衣人是违背神圣誓言的圣骑士，他们现在沉溺于自己的恶棍野心。他们与恶魔和亡灵交媾，他们拒绝接受他们以前生活中的许多美好事物。
黑衣人通常用可怕的装备来装饰他们的盔甲和武器，或者用阴森恐怖的现象来标记。你可以选择一个黑衣人的装备，或者在黑衣人装备表上滚动来决定它。

entries.caption: Blackguard Accoutrements
rows: 蚀刻着可怕的战斗的风格化描述的盔甲
锻造成恶魔野猪形状的头盔
锻造成死亡面具的头盔
卷曲的墨色烟雾从盔甲的接合处渗出
几十只苍蝇在黑衣人身上嗡嗡作响
挂在黑衣人脖子上的链子上的断手
饰有 "我选择暴力 "字样的长布的匕首

entries: 寻找被遗忘的传说和失落的遗迹，蓝色阿比西斯是他们中最狡猾和博学的人。他们对从整个多元宇宙掠夺来的书籍中收集到的神秘主题的研究使他们能够成为有成就的施法者。他们用他们的魔法来摧毁提亚马特的敌人。

monsterFluff.name: Bodak
entries: 波达克是崇尚奥库斯的人的不朽遗体。它没有生命和灵魂，只为造成死亡而存在。
对奥库斯的崇拜者可以在胸前心脏上方刻下恶魔领主的符号时进行仪式性的宣誓。奥库斯的力量会剥去身体、思想和灵魂，留下一个有生命的躯壳，吞噬附近的生命能量。大多数波达克以这种方式出现，然后被释放出来，以奥库斯的名义传播死亡。
波达克是奥库斯的意志在深渊之外的延伸，为恶魔王子的目标和其他爪牙服务。奥卡斯可以回忆起波达克看到或听到的任何东西。如果他愿意，他可以通过波达克直接对他的敌人和追随者说话。
波达克保留着对其过去生活的模糊印象。它寻找它以前的盟友和敌人来摧毁他们，因为它扭曲的灵魂试图抹去任何与它以前的生活有关的东西。奥库斯的奴仆是这种强迫性的一个例外；波达克承认他们是同类的灵魂，并将他们从它的愤怒中拯救出来。任何在它变成波达克之前认识它的人都能认出它的行为举止或其他关于其原始身份的微妙线索。

monsterFluff.name: Boggle
entries: Boggles是童话故事中的小妖怪。它们潜伏在精灵世界的边缘地带，在物质世界也能找到，它们藏在床底下和壁橱里，等待着用它们的恶作剧来吓唬和困扰人们。
Boggles诞生于孤独的感觉。当一个有生命的人感到被孤立或被遗弃在精灵世界接触到的地方时，他们就会出现。例如，一个被遗弃的孩子可能无意中变出一个博格，并将它们视为一种想象中的朋友。博格也可能出现在一个孤独的鳏夫家的阁楼上或隐士的山洞里。
博格犬从事小规模的恶作剧以自娱自乐，用它们排泄的油来制造麻烦。博格犬也不至于打碎碗碟、藏匿工具、惊吓奶牛以减少牛奶，或将婴儿藏在阁楼上。尽管博格犬的滑稽行为可能会造成困扰和无意的伤害，但恶作剧--而不是混乱--通常是它的意图。如果受到威胁，博格犬会逃跑，而不是站着战斗。
博格可以创造出神奇的开口来进行短距离的旅行，或者偷窃本来无法触及的物品。要在空间中创造这样的裂缝，boggle必须与一个由框架定义的空间相邻，比如一扇打开的窗户或一个门口，一个笼子的栅栏之间的缝隙，或一张床的脚和地板之间的开口。裂缝是{@condition invisible}，并在几秒钟后消失--正好有足够的时间让boggle通过它进行踩踏、接触或攻击。

monsterFluff.name: Boneclaw
entries: 一个试图成为巫师但失败的巫师可能会变成一个骨爪。这些狰狞的、咯咯作响的怪物与巫师有一些相同的属性，但巫师是不朽的奥术大师，而骨爪则是邪恶、仇恨和痛苦的奴隶。
变身仪式最重要的部分发生在有抱负的巫师的灵魂迁移到一个准备好的法器上。如果巫师的身体或魔法太弱，无法强迫灵魂进入它的新家，那么灵魂就会寻找一个主人--在几英里范围内有一颗充满仇恨的心的人。灵魂与那个人结合，成为新主人愿望的奴隶。骨爪在它的主人身边形成，有时出现在那个人面前接受命令，有时只是寻求满足它主人的愿望。
一个骨爪只能为邪恶的生物服务。如果它的主人找到了救赎，或者真诚地离开了邪恶的道路，骨爪就会被摧毁。否则，只要它的主人还活着，骨爪就不会被摧毁。无论骨爪的身体发生什么，它都会在数小时内重新形成。
为了服务于它的主人，骨爪以造成可怕的痛苦为乐。它像蜘蛛一样潜伏在阴暗的角落里，等待着受害者接近它那长长的骨质肢体。一旦被刺中，生物就会被拉入黑暗中，被切成碎片。

monsterFluff.name: Brontosaurus
entries: 这种巨大的四足恐龙体型庞大，大多数捕食者都会放过它。它致命的尾巴可以赶走或杀死较小的威胁。

monsterFluff.name: Bulezau

entries: 有些人问，为什么Bulezau的所有愤怒和暴力，都有一个山羊的头。我总是回答，你见过山羊吗？它们很顽固，很凶恶，而且它们很少不在你的小腿上打几下就倒下。
你可能会说，这太具体了。我说，别打听了。
兽性愤怒的病态表现，bulezaus体现了大自然的暴力。在整个深渊，这些恶魔潜伏在深邃的峡谷和高耸的峭壁中，许多人在恶魔领主的军队中找到了一席之地，在深渊的无尽战争中充当步兵。
Bulezaus渴望暴力。他们对杀戮的渴望和死亡的意愿使他们成为许多恶魔领主的随从的常见成员。当没有被更大更强悍的恶魔收编时，Bulezaus会聚集成争抢的暴徒，在他们之间进行搏斗，直到有更好的目标出现，或者直到有更强大的恶魔欺负他们，让他们屈服。
毁容性疾病困扰着Bulezaus：眼睛结痂，蛆虫在敞开的疮口中蠕动，无论他们走到哪里，都有一股腐烂的肉臭味。

monsterFluff.name: Cadaver Collector
entries: 被称为尸体收集器的古老战争机器漫无目的地在阿凯隆的爆炸平原上游荡，直到它们被一个死灵法师召唤，以加强物质界上的征服军的队伍。这些可怕的建筑服从他们的召唤者，直到他们被遣送回阿凯隆，但如果召唤者的结局不好，尸体收集者可能会在物质界游荡几个世纪，一边收集尸体一边寻找回家的方法。
尸体收集者只有在被召唤到大战现场时才会回应凡人的召唤--要么是正在进行的大战，要么是即将发生的大战，要么是曾经发生过大战的地方。他们将自己包裹在阵亡战士的盔甲和武器中，并将这些战士的尸体钉在长矛和其他嵌入其残余盔甲的武器上。
堆积在尸体收集者外壳上的尸体不仅仅是可怕的战斗战利品。尸体收集者可以召唤这些尸体的灵魂来与敌人作战。虽然这些幽灵个体很弱，但如果有足够的时间，尸体收集者可以召唤出几乎无穷无尽的幽灵。

monsterFluff.name: Canoloth

entries: 卡诺罗特是光荣的护卫犬。如果你必须与之交战，只需弄清楚它被指派做什么。我经常发现，只要利用相关的漏洞，我就可以从他们身边走过。
作为尤格罗特的一种类型，卡诺罗特是邪恶势力雇佣的恶魔般的追踪者和守护者。他们更喜欢签订合同来保护有价值的宝物和重要地点。他们总是严格按照要求行事--从不多做，也从不少做。
卡诺拉的感官足够敏锐，可以准确地确定附近（%0%）生物的位置，对任何威胁到它们的指控都会做出不折不扣的反应。此外，它们会发出一种神奇的扭曲场，阻止靠近它们的生物进行传送。卡诺拉斯以迅速而可怕的力量对抗入侵者，伸出长长的、带刺的舌头抓住它们的敌人并把它们拖近。接下来会发生什么，取决于契约的内容。除非被指示杀戮，卡诺拉斯只是抓着它的俘虏，但如果被命令这样做，它就会把猎物的肢体撕碎。

monsterFluff.name: Catoblepas
entries: Catoblepas和它生活的沼泽地一样令人厌恶，它是由臃肿的水牛、恐龙、疣猪和河马的部分组成的。尽管它的生理结构很不雅观，但猫鼬的行为却很像自然界的动物，它在沼泽地的家园里埋头苦干，啃食选择的植物，偶尔吃一点腐肉，并在泥沼中沉溺。一只猫鼬可能会和它选择的一个伴侣一起生活，有时也会和一只小牛一起生活。一只猫鼬会攻击任何走得太近的人，尤其是在看守它的幼崽时。
Catoblepas的臭味，就像死亡的臭味与沼气和臭鼬的麝香混合在一起，让人觉得它比它的外表所显示的要可怕得多。当它开始攻击时，catoblepas就会显示出它的恐怖性质。这种生物的蛇形颈部很难抬起它的头，但它那充满血丝的眼睛一瞪，就能让肉体腐烂。在它的尾巴末端有一根棍子，如果它真的打中了，可以使身体和灵魂摇摇欲坠，让受害者无法行动，而鲶鱼则在其身体上大快朵颐。

entries.name: Blighted Territory
entries: Catoblepas作为一种疾病和腐烂的生物，在其沼泽地的栖息地中也呈现出类似的特征。这样的湿地会变得阴暗、纠结，而且比以前更加腥臭。环境中有益的品质，如治疗的草药和干净的水，变得退化了，沼泽的气体也有了一丝猫鼬的臭味。该地区的动物更具攻击性，容易生病。堕落的生物很可能会在猫鼬的领地附近居住，那些想要避免被注意的生物也是如此。

entries.name: Catoblepas in Folklore
entries: 普通人很少看到catoblepas，但这种生物有如此可怕的声誉，以至于关于它的故事在大众文化中根深蒂固。任何关于猫鼬在附近居住的传言都被认为是一个坏兆头，即使这个传言被证明是假的。在一些地方，猫头鹰的轮廓，其尾巴延伸到身体上，头低着，是一个邪恶的预示图形，象征着死亡或厄运。
圣人说，瘟疫和腐烂之神创造了catoblepases，作为其影响力的体现，而其他故事则将它们与不幸联系起来。一些这样的故事声称，居住在沼泽地的女巫像养牛一样照顾catoblepases，喝怪物的奶，把它们当作监护人或宠物。还有一些传说说，那些心地不纯的人可以驯服catoblepas，并低声说，恶毒的术士和邪恶的骑士会骑着它们去战斗。

entries.name: Cattle
entries: 许多种类的牛在多元宇宙中游荡，其中一些是被驯化的，另一些是野生的。在许多文化中，牛几乎就像照顾它们的人的家人。

monsterFluff.name: Cave Fisher
entries: 洞穴鱼人是一种地下蛛形纲动物，有一个长长的鼻子，里面有喷丝器，使该生物能够产生粘性的丝线，很像蜘蛛的网线，该生物利用这些丝线来捕获猎物。
洞穴捕鱼者通常猎杀小动物，特别喜欢蝙蝠，所以它在这种猎物可能通过的开口上拉出一根丝。然后，它爬到一个隐蔽的地方，把自己贴在表面休息和等待。当猎物误入丝线时，洞穴捕鱼者就会卷起它的食物。一群洞穴捕鱼者可能会一起工作，用丝线覆盖一大片区域，但只要有一只捕到了潜在的食物，该地区的每一只洞穴捕鱼者都会争夺这个奖品。如果一个受害者从最初的埋伏中逃脱，洞穴捕鱼者可以通过射出丝线再次捕获猎物来夺回它。
稀缺的食物可能会吸引一群洞穴捕鱼者上到地面，进入一个阴暗的峡谷或阴暗的森林，其中既有本地动物的猎物，也有探险家或旅行者等生物偶尔经过的地方。

entries.name: Valuable Parts
entries: Nearly every part of a cave fisher is useful after the creature has been dispatched. Cave fisher filaments can be woven into rope that is thin, tough, and nearly invisible. The creature's shell is used in the manufacture of tools, armor, and jewelry. Its blood is alcoholic and tastes like strong liquor. Several dwarven spirits include cave fisher blood, and some dwarves, especially berserkers, drink the blood straight. Cave fisher meat is edible, tasting much like crab cooked in strong wine.

While some folk hunt cave fishers to kill them to harvest their filaments, shells, and blood, others capture cave fisher eggs and rear the hatchlings, which can be trained to guard passages or serve as beasts of war. Cave fishers have a natural aversion to fire, since their blood is flammable. As such, Underdark denizens often use the threat of fire when training them.

monsterFluff.name: Champion

entries: Bountiful and overrated. You can't spit in this realm without hitting one. I have witnessed the birth, death, and unlife of more champions than I dare recount. Few are worth remembering.

Champions are mighty warriors who have honed their fighting skills in wars or gladiatorial pits. To soldiers and other people who fight for a living, champions are as influential as nobles, and their presence is courted as a sign of status among rulers.

A typical champion bears a coat of arms, heraldry that is associated with the champion far and wide. You may create a coat of arms for a champion or roll on the Champion's Coats of Arms table to determine it.

entries.caption: Champion's Coat of Arms
rows: Three lit candles on a purple field
Sea serpent coiled around a trident on a blue field
Hunting horn banded in gold on a gray field
Raised fist grasping an anchor on a quartered field of blue and white
Turtle with crenelated tower on its shell on a white field
Dragon skull supported on either side by dragon wings on a red field
Yellow chicken foot on a black field
Lightning bolt splitting a galley in two on a blue field
Two crouching displacer beasts facing each other on a yellow field
Knotted brambles on a green field
Red owlbear with a silver crown on a checkered field of black and white
Black anvil cracked down the middle on an orange field

monsterFluff.name: Chitine
entries: Dedicated to Lolth, chitines are multiarmed bipeds with arachnid qualities. Most live in colonies in the Underdark and fight the enemies of the Demon Queen of Spiders. Long ago, the cult of Lolth first subjected elf prisoners to horrible rituals that transformed them into creatures with both elven and spider traits, which their creators dubbed chitines. The intention was to create servile warriors dedicated first to the cult and then, only by association with it, to Lolth. The goddess found this arrangement unacceptable.

As punishment, the Spider Queen twisted her worshipers' rituals. The process usually transformed subjects into the spindly creatures her devotees expected, but occasionally, an elf changed into a choldrith: an arachnid Monstrosity able to command and create more chitines on its own. These choldriths soon led the chitines to rebel and abandon their creators, founding free colonies elsewhere in the Underdark. On occasion, though, colonies can be found in remote, gloomy areas of the surface world, warring against Lolth's enemies.

The cult of Lolth still creates chitines as the need arises. Outside the presence of a choldrith, chitines make good workers, and they can be useful if the cult finds an independent chitine colony and want to infiltrate it. If the creation process yields a choldrith, though, the cult destroys the creature.

As servants of Lolth, chitines love spiders. They rear spiders and similar arachnids, such as cave fishers (also in this book). Chitine colonies erect shrines to Lolth that serve as beacons, attracting spiders and other beings that serve her. Anywhere chitines set up a colony quickly becomes a webshrouded, gloomy, and treacherous place.

Chitines resemble spiders, but they behave more like social insects such as ants. They are divided into worker and warrior castes; choldriths, when present, occupy the top levels of a colony's hierarchy. Each chitine has a social position that comes with duties related to that rank, and all are expected to sacrifice themselves to protect the colony's choldriths. Every chitine has spinnerets and slowly produces webbing that is used to build floors, walls, structures, objects, and traps that benefit the colony. A warrior might be responsible for crafting web armor (which is as tough as hide or leather), while a group of workers might be tasked to dig pit traps and cover them with fragile webbing disguised with loose dirt to appear as a solid surface.

monsterFluff.name: Choker
entries: The choker is a subterranean predator far more dangerous than its small size and spindly, rubbery limbs would suggest.

Chokers have cartilage rather than a bony skeleton. This flexible internal structure enables them to easily slip into narrow fissures and niches in the walls of their cavern homes. They lurk in these spots, silent and unseen, waiting for prey to happen by.

A choker's usual method for luring prey involves positioning the body of its latest catch just outside its hiding spot. Whenever it gets hungry, it tears off a few chunks of flesh to feed itself. In the meantime, the corpse serves to entice other curious folk—explorers from the surface world, drow, duergar, or the choker's favorite prey, goblins—to come within reach.

When a target presents itself, the choker's starfish-shaped hands dart out of its hiding spot, wrap around the victim's throat, and pin the unfortunate creature against the cavern wall. Because its arms are so long, the choker can keep its body deep inside the crevice where it hides, beyond the reach of most normal weapons.

Chokers tend to set their ambushes alone, rather than working in concert, but where one choker is found, others are likely to be nearby. They communicate through eerie, keening howls that travel long distances through caves and tunnels but are difficult to identify or locate in a typical echo-filled cavern.

monsterFluff.name: Choldrith
entries: Choldriths are monstrous spiderlike creatures originally created to serve Lolth. They rule colonies of chitines (in this book) and lead them into battle in Lolth's war against her enemies.

When devotees of Lolth created the first chitines, she watched as her followers used arcane magic and demonic powers and invoked her aid for the divine spark needed to ensure the subjects' survival, expecting to see these new abominations dedicated solely to her, but the devotees performed no such ritual. As revenge for the devotees' betrayal, the Spider Queen manipulated the creation rituals so that they sometimes created choldriths instead of chitines.

At first, these devotees were unaware that the new creatures, which they dubbed choldriths, were signs of Lolth's wrath. Instead, they were pleased, because choldriths could lay eggs that birthed more chitines (and the rare choldrith) and could direct the chitines in their work. But the devotees soon realized their mistake—choldriths belonged to Lolth, body and soul. Choldriths whispered to the chitines of their adoration of the Spider Queen and their enmity against their creators, and led them in a successful revolt.

Choldriths are born with a mystical connection to Lolth, which gives them divine magic. They also make up the ruling caste of most chitine colonies. A colony can support numerous choldriths, who serve as commanders, priests, and supervisors. The choldriths continually jockey for position, although they rarely confront one another in a way that puts the colony at risk. The colony is ruled by a sovereign, who determines which colony members perform which tasks, including whether a choldrith is permitted to lay eggs. Sometimes a choldrith ruler receives a vision from Lolth that inspires the entire colony into some grand, often violent, action.

A bronze scout seldom emerges from underground. Its telescoping eyestalks observe foes at close range while most of its segmented body remains buried. If detected, it sends electrical shocks through the ground toward pursuers while it retreats.
An iron cobra is exactly what its name implies: a metal snake with a poisonous bite. Gnomes load this clockwork with alchemical concoctions that can paralyze creatures and cloud the mind.

No ordinary ballista, an oaken bolter is a Construct capable of striking at long distances. The bolts it launches can rend flesh, destroy armor, or drag enemies toward traps or melee-oriented clockworks—and at shorter ranges, burst with explosive force.
The thick plates of stone riveted onto a stone {@item defender} give it substantial protection. Its chief role is as a bodyguard.

entries.name: Clockworks
entries: Gnomes' tinkering with magic and mechanical devices has produced many failed Constructs but also has resulted in genuine advances, such as clockworks. The methods used to craft clockworks have been shared between gnome communities over many generations.

entries.name: Individual Designs
entries: Gnome artisans prefer unique clockworks over perfectly functioning ones that copy too much from other creations. A clockwork can be customized by adding one of the following enhancements and one potential malfunction to its stat block. You can select randomly or choose a pair of modifications that fit the temperament of the clockwork's builder.

entries.caption: Clockwork Enhancements
rows: {@b Camouflaged.} The clockwork gains proficiency in {@skill Stealth} if it lacks that proficiency. While motionless, it is indistinguishable from a stopped machine.
{@b Sensors.} The range of the clockwork's {@sense darkvision} increases by 60 feet, and it gains proficiency in {@skill Perception} if it lacks that proficiency.
{@b Fortified.} The clockwork's AC increases by 2.
{@b Increased Speed.} The clockwork's speed increases by 10 feet.
{@b Reinforced Construction.} The clockwork has resistance to force, lightning, and thunder damage.

{@b Self-Repairing.} If the clockwork starts its turn with fewer than half its hit points but at least 1 hit point, it regains 5 hit points. If it takes lightning damage, this ability doesn't function at the start of its next turn.
{@b Sturdy Frame.} The clockwork's hit point maximum increases by an amount equal to its number of Hit Dice.
{@b Suction.} The clockwork gains a climbing speed of 30 feet.
{@b Vocal Resonator.} The clockwork gains the ability to speak rudimentary Common or Gnomish.
{@b Water Propulsion.} The clockwork gains a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.caption: Clockwork Malfunctions
rows: {@b Faulty Sensors.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clock work's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork is {@condition blinded} until the end of its turn.
{@b Flawed Targeting.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clock work's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork makes attack rolls with disadvantage until the end of its turn.
{@b Ground Fault.} The clockwork has vulnerability to lightning damage.

{@b Imprinting Loop.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clock work's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork mistakes one creature it can see within 30 feet for its creator. The clockwork won't willingly harm that creature for 1 minute or until that creature attacks or dam ages it.

{@b Limited Steering.} The clockwork must move in a straight line. It can turn up to 90 degrees before moving and again at the midpoint of its movement. It can rotate freely if it doesn't use any of its speeds on its turn.

{@b Overactive Sense of Self-Preservation.} If the clock work has half its hit points or fewer at the start of its turn in combat, roll a {@dice d6}. If you roll a 1, it retreats from combat if possible. It otherwise keeps fighting.
{@b Overheats.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its turn.
{@b Rusty Gears.} The clockwork has disadvantage on initiative rolls, and its speed decreases by 10 feet.

monsterFluff.name: Cloud Giant Smiling One
entries: Smiling ones are cloud giants who honor and emulate the craftiness and deceit of the deity Memnor above all else. They are tricksters supreme who use sleight of hand, deception, misdirection, and magic in their pursuit of wealth. They also possess a flair for unpredictability and a wicked sense of humor. Smiling ones overstep all bounds of decorum with their behavior, doing and saying things that even other knavish folk consider beneath their dignity.

Smiling ones take their name from the strange two-faced masks they wear. The smiling half of the face often looks more like a smirk or a triumphant sneer than a pleasant grin. The frowning half represents the displeasure smiling ones feel about cloud giants' place in the ordning—second to storm giants. The masks serve as symbols of smiling ones' devotion and also conceal their wearers' true facial expressions.
Conjurers summon creatures from other planes of existence and teleport themselves and others in the blink of an eye.

monsterFluff.name: Corpse Flower
entries: A corpse flower can sprout atop the grave of an evil necromancer or the remains of powerful Undead creatures. Unless it is uprooted and burned while it is still a seedling, the corpse flower grows to enormous size over several weeks, then tears itself free of the earth and begins scavenging Humanoid corpses from battlefields and graveyards. Using its fibrous tentacles, it stuffs the remains into its body to sustain and repair itself. The plant has a malevolent bent and despises the living.

With or without corpses nested in its body, a corpse flower exudes a stench of decay that can overwhelm the senses of nearby creatures, causing them to become nauseated. The stench, which serves as a defense mechanism, fades {@dice 2d4} days after the corpse flower dies.

entries.name: Cranium Rat
entries: Mind flayers create cranium rats by bombarding rats with psionic energy. Cranium rats are somewhat smarter than ordinary rats and behave as such. If enough cranium rats come together to form a swarm, they merge their minds into a single intelligence with the accumulated memories of all the swarm's constituents. The rats become smarter as a result, and retain their heightened intelligence for as long as the swarm persists. The swarm also awakens latent psionic abilities implanted within each cranium rat by its mind flayer creators, bestowing upon the swarm psionic powers.

A single cranium rat uses its natural telepathy to communicate hunger, fear, and other base emotions. A swarm of cranium rats communicating telepathically "speaks" as one creature, often referring to itself using the collective pronouns "we" and "us." Some mind flayer colonies use cranium rats as spies. The rats invade communities and act as eyes and ears for the colony's elder brain, transmitting their thoughts when they swarm and are within range of the elder brain's telepathy.

The Summer Queen's curse causes a darkling's body to absorb light, which wizens the creature, much like the effect of rapid aging. For this reason, darklings cover their entire bodies with clothing when exposure to light is a risk. The light darklings absorb over the course of their lives explodes outward when they die, incinerating the creatures and much of their possessions.

A wise and respected darkling can undergo a ritual to become an elder. Other elders mark the supplicant with glowing tattoos, channeling away some of the darkling's absorbed light. If the ritual succeeds, the darkling grows into a taller, elf-like form. The darkling perishes if the ritual fails.

entries.name: Darklings
entries: Ancient legends speak of a seelie fey who betrayed the Summer Queen. In the Summer Queens' wrath, she cursed every member of his house. The seelie fey's true name has been stricken from history, but the stories call him Dubh Catha ("Dark Crow" in Common), and other Fey refer to the house's descendants as dubh sith—"darklings." Darklings dwell in secluded caverns and chambers beneath the towns of other species. From such enclaves, they quietly ply their trade as thieves and assassins.

monsterFluff.name: Death Kiss
entries: A death kiss is a lesser beholder that can come into being when a true beholder has a vivid nightmare about losing blood. Its coloration and shape resemble those of the beholder that dreamed it into existence, but its hue is more muted, and instead of magical eye rays, it has ten long tentacles, each ending in a mouth full of teeth. It can speak through any of its tentacle-maws in a high-pitched, nasal voice.

Death kisses fear true beholders, which can easily kill or subdue them. Lacking the egotism of their stronger kin, a death kiss usually submits to the rule of its creator or any other beholder it encounters, but it tries to escape as soon as the beholder is preoccupied.

A death kiss consumes ingested blood, which it also uses to heal and generate electrical energy inside its body. Terrified of dying from starvation, it obsessively drains even little creatures such as rats, leaving behind a trail of bloodless corpses. When underground, it uses its tentacles as feelers, prodding and examining the environment in all directions. Above ground, it usually keeps its tentacles retracted when on the hunt, then lashes out with them to catch opponents off guard.

A death kiss lacks the combat finesse and intelligence of a true beholder. In most cases, it simply latches on to its prey with one or more of its tentacles and drains blood until the prey collapses. If it's in a superior position and its foe poses no threat, it might toy with its food, drawing out its prey's death. A death kiss prefers to hunt alone. If it meets another of its kind, it might fight, flee, or team up, depending on its health and pride.

An overpowering urge to serve consumes the mind of a newly awakened deathlock. Any goals and ambitions it had in life that don't please its patron fall away as its master's desires become the purpose that drives it. The deathlock immediately resumes work on its patron's behalf.

Whatever the goal, it always reflects the patron's interests, ranging from small-scale concerns to matters of cosmic scope. A deathlock in the thrall of a Fiend might work to destroy a specific temple dedicated to a good god, while one that serves a Great Old One might hunt for the materials needed to call forth a horrifying entity into the world. To accomplish a difficult goal, the deathlock might be forced to serve another powerful creature or might need to gather servants of its own.

Though deathlocks exist to serve their patrons, they retain some freedom when it comes to devising tactics and carrying out plans. Powerful deathlocks recruit lesser creatures to help them carry out their missions, becoming the masterminds behind vast conspiracies and intrigues that culminate in the accomplishment of great acts of evil.
Deprived of much of its magic as a special punishment, a deathlock wight lingers between the warlock it was and the wretched existence of a wight.

entries.name: Deathlocks
entries: The forging of a pact between a warlock and a patron is no minor occasion—at least not for the warlock. The consequences of breaking that pact can be dire and, in some cases, lethal. A warlock who fails to live up to a bargain with an evil patron runs the risk of rising from the dead as a deathlock, a foul Undead driven to serve its otherworldly patron.
An powerful necromancer might also discover the wicked methods of creating a deathlock and then subjugate it, acting as the deathlock's patron.

Deep rothe are Underdark cattle that communicate with one another using the dancing lights spell. Some scholars speculate that rothe came originally from the Feywild and brought the ability to cast the spell with them. Other sages attribute the ability to the centuries rothe have spent in the Underdark, where ambient magic slowly transforms everything.

monsterFluff.name: Deep Scion
entries: Deep scions began life as people who were stolen from shore or saved from sinking ships and offered a terrible bargain by an undersea power: surrender, body and soul, or drown. Those who submit are subjected to an ancient ritual widespread among evil aquatic creatures. Its methods are painful and the result never certain, but when it works, the magic transforms an air-breathing person into a shapeshifter that can take on an aquatic form.

A deep scion emerges from the depths in service to their underwater master, which is likely a kraken or some other ancient being of the deep. While wearing the mind and body of the person they once were as a sort of mask, the creature is bent on fulfilling their master's desires. Sometimes a deep scion returns to their former home—unexpectedly found alive when all hope was lost. At other times the deep scion takes on a new identity. In any case, it is the deep scion's duty to infiltrate the air-breathing world and report back to their master. When set to this task, a deep scion worms their way into the life of an unsuspecting enemy as a new friend, a lover, the perfect candidate for a job, or some other role that enables the minion to carry out their master's commands.

The training to which a deep scion is subjected rids it of empathy for those they spy on. Though a deep scion might behave as though infatuated, laugh at the joke of a friend, or appear incensed at some injustice, each of these acts is artificial to the deep scion, a means to an end. The creature believes that their true form is the shape they take when they return to the sea they think of as home. Ironically, however, a deep scion that is killed when in their piscine form is stripped of the magic that enabled them to transform, leaving behind the corpse of the person the deep scion once was.

monsterFluff.name: Deinonychus
entries: This larger cousin of the velociraptor kills by gripping its target with its claws and feeding.

monsterFluff.name: Demogorgon

entries: Are two heads better than one? In Demogorgon's case, the two double the horror and the chaos.

Prince of Demons, the Sibilant Beast, and Master of the Spiraling Depths, Demogorgon is the embodiment of chaos, confusion, and destruction, seeking to corrupt all that is good and undermine order in the multiverse, to see everything dragged howling into the infinite depths of the Abyss.

The demon lord is a meld of different forms. He has a saurian lower body and clawed, webbed feet; suckered tentacles sprout from the shoulders of his great apelike torso, which is surmounted by two hideous simian heads named Aameul and Hathradiah. Their gaze brings bewilderment and confusion to any who confront them.
Similarly, the spiraling Y sign of Demogorgon's cult drives those who contemplate it for too long to delirium. As a result, all followers of the Prince of Demons break with reality sooner or later.

entries.name: Cultists of Demogorgon
entries: {@note See the {@cult Cult of Demogorgon|MPMM} entry.}

entries.name: Demogorgon's Lair
entries: Demogorgon makes his lair in a palace called Abysm, found on a layer of the Abyss known as the Gaping Maw. Demogorgon's lair is a place of confusion and duality; the portion of the palace that lies above water takes the form of two serpentine towers, each crowned by a skull-shaped minaret. There, Demogorgon's heads contemplate the mysteries of the arcane while arguing about how best to obliterate their rivals. The bulk of this palace extends deep underwater, in chill and darkened caverns.

monsterFluff.name: Derro

entries: Mind flayers must be stopped. They have visited horrors on countless worlds, and entire groups of people have been mutated by illithid experiments. Such are the derro.
Whenever I've met them, I refuse to fight, no matter how violent they might be. I think of the dwarves they once were. and I must confess that even I have shed tears.

Derro slink through the subterranean realms, seeking places that are safe from the perils of the Underdark. Equal parts fearful and vicious, bands of these dwarf-kin prey on those weaker than themselves, while giving simpering obeisance to any creatures they deem more powerful. A lone derro may seem pitiable, but a cackling, spitting, growling, howling horde of them is horrifying to behold.

Fractious in groups and individually weak, derro would have died out long ago but for two elements of their character. They are cautious and distrustful, which serves them well as they navigate the dangers of the Underdark and its societies. They also have a stronger-than-normal tendency to develop sorcerous power. Individuals who do so usually serve as leaders and are known as savants.

Grandiose fantasies and rampant fanaticism have obscured derro's true origin, even among themselves. Most dwarves don't recognize derro as kin, but the legends that derro tell about their people and the story that duergar believe share a grain of truth. According to the histories of some duergar, derro are descended from a dwarven community that was left behind when the others escaped the rule of mind flayers. These remnants were so distorted by the mind flayers' psionic power that the dwarves became Aberrations.

Derro tell their own stories of flight and survival in the Underdark, in which mind flayers aren't always the enemy. They tell of two brothers, the gods Diirinka and Diinkarazan, and of how Diirinka cleverly betrayed his sibling so that he could steal magical power from the evil they escaped. The danger the brothers are said to face in this legend varies, depending on whatever foe the savants want to lead their people against, yet the essence of the story remains the same: a lesson of survival at any price and an example of how deceitfulness and cruelty can be virtues.

monsterFluff.name: Devourer
entries: Of all the abominations unleashed by {@creature Orcus|MPMM}, devourers are among the most feared. These tall, mummy-like Undead wander the planes, consuming souls and spreading Orcus's creed of replacing all life with everlasting death.

A lesser demon that proves itself to Orcus might be granted the privilege of becoming a devourer. The Prince of Undeath transforms such a demon into an 8-foot-tall, desiccated biped with a hollowed-out ribcage, then fills the new creature with a hunger for souls. Orcus grants each new devourer the essence of a less fortunate demon to power the devourer's first foray into the planes. Most devourers remain in the Abyss or on the Astral or Ethereal Plane, pursuing Orcus's schemes and interests in those realms. When Orcus sends devourers to the Material Plane, he often sets them on a mission to create, control, and lead a plague of Undead. {@creature skeleton||Skeletons}, {@creature zombie||zombies}, {@creature ghoul||ghouls}, {@creature ghast||ghasts}, and {@creature shadow||shadows} are particularly attracted to the presence of a devourer.

Devourers hunt Humanoids with the intent of consuming them body and soul. After a devourer brings a target to the brink of death, it pulls the victim's body in and traps the creature within its own ribcage. As the victim tries to stave off death (usually without success), the devourer tortures its soul with telepathic noise. When the victim expires, it undergoes a horrible transformation, springing forth from the devourer's body to begin its new existence as an Undead servitor of the monster that spawned it.

monsterFluff.name: Dhergoloth

entries: A dhergoloth's head doesn't turn along with its furiously spinning torso, and its torso can spin a different direction from its dancing legs.
I'd like to vivisect one a some point to find out how this can be.

A kind of yugoloth, dhergoloths rush into battle like whirlwinds of destruction, lashing out with the five sets of claws that extend from their squat, barrel-shaped bodies. They take contracts to put down uprisings, clear out rabble, and eliminate scouts and skirmishers, and they revel in the butchery they create, their gleeful laughter rising above their victims' screams.

Since dhergoloths are little more than brutes, employers must use caution when instructing them. They can handle simple orders that don't take a lot of time to resolve. When given anything complex to do, however, they either forget what they're told or don't listen in the first place, and then bungle the task that was set for them.

monsterFluff.name: Dimetrodon
entries: This sail-backed reptile is commonly found in areas where dinosaurs live. It hunts on shores and in shallow water, filling a similar role to a crocodile.

Trolls kill and eat almost anything—including, in rare cases, other trolls. This cannibalism has the effect of causing a troll to grow to an unusually large size. The resulting dire trolls crave more and more troll flesh to fuel their continued growth.

Dire trolls also increase their size by grafting flesh onto themselves. When a slab of quivering troll flesh is bound against a fresh wound on a dire troll, the dire troll's regenerative capacity incorporates the new mass into the troll's own musculature. Even more horrifying are the multiple arms, eyes, claws, and organs that dire trolls tear from their victims and graft onto themselves in this manner.

Diviners peer into the future and know that knowledge is power. They might act aloof and mysterious, hinting at omens and secrets, or they might be know-it-alls, spilling insights to advance their own status.

Dolphins are symbols of wisdom and playfulness among the sea folk of many worlds. Found in oceans and in the Elemental Plane of Water, dolphins are befriended by druids and rangers, and many tales speak of dolphins that appeared out of nowhere to protect swimmers from sharks and other aquatic predators.

In the Feywild, dolphin delighters brighten the moods of those who travel the seas of the Domains of Delight. Telepathically singing sea chanteys, these dolphins leap and teleport through the luminous waters of Faerie and the Material Plane, and they are faithful allies to any who battle the forces of gloom and brutality under the waves.
Dolphin delighters often accompany groups of sea elves, tritons, and tortles as guardians and friends.

entries.name: Dolphins
entries: Dolphins are clever, social marine mammals that feed on small fish and squid. An adult specimen is between 5 and 6 feet long.

monsterFluff.name: Draegloth
entries: A draegloth is a demon created by an elf priest of Lolth in an unholy, dangerous ritual in which it is infused with the fey essence of the creator and the fiendish essence of a {@creature glabrezu}. This ritual rarely succeeds, but Lolth's faithful consider it worth the risk, as the resulting creature is gifted with innate magic and physical might. The draegloth usually serves its creator, lending its thirst for destruction to the creator's plans to triumph over rivals.

A draegloth is an ogre-sized, four-armed biped with purple skin and pale hair. Two of its arms are muscular, tipped with sharp claws; the other two are the size and shape of an elf's arms, capable of delicate movements. Although the creature is heavily muscled, it is graceful like an elf. Its bestial face features glowing red eyes, a doglike snout, and a mouth full of sharp teeth.

Among the drow noble houses of Menzoberranzan in the Forgotten Realms, a high priestess's successful creation of a draegloth is seen as a sign of Lolth's favor toward her house—and a sign of the demon lord's disregard for the family's rivals, who were not thus gifted. The creation prompts the leaders of the house to begin crafting new plans to strike at its rivals when the draegloth is fully grown. These plans use the draegloth in a significant role, because its abilities can turn the tide in a battle against a house that doesn't have a draegloth of its own.

Although draegloths plays an important part in the plans of Lolth's cult, a draegloth can't rise above the status of a favored servant to a priest in that cult. Before a draegloth is given any duties, it receives instruction in accepting the role set for it and not challenging authority. Most draegloths fiercely resent being given orders, but thanks to their training, they typically take out their frustration on their creator's enemies, rather than on their creator. A draegloth that can't suppress its ambitions might abandon its creator and strike out on its own. Whether these rebellious draegloths are part of Lolth's plan for sowing chaos is unclear.

monsterFluff.name: Drow Arachnomancer
entries: Drow spellcasters who seek to devote themselves wholly to {@deity Lolth|Drow|MTF}, the Spider Queen, sometimes walk the sinister path of the arachnomancer. By offering up body and soul to Lolth, they gain tremendous power and a supernatural connection to the ancient spiders of the Demonweb Pits, channeling magic from that dread place.

monsterFluff.name: Drow Favored Consort
entries: Nearly every priestess of {@deity Lolth|Drow|MTF}, including the powerful {@creature drow matron mother|MPMM} in this book, takes an attractive drow as consort. Chosen as much for beauty as for magical might, a drow favored consort can hold their own in both conversation and combat. Combining the roles of advisor, protector, and beloved, some favored consorts are content with a supporting role, while more ambitious consorts aspire to be the power behind the throne—or even to claim the throne themselves.

Those favored consorts who prove their cunning gain the ear, and perhaps even the heart, of their priestess and are relied on to provide useful advice. No position of consort is assured for long, though; Lolth's priestesses are notoriously fickle, and a consort must often contend with rivals.

Some favored consorts work behind the scenes to undermine the evils encouraged by Lolth. Others can be found in Underdark cities free of Lolth's influence, where these powerful spellcasters apply their might toward ending her tyranny.

monsterFluff.name: Drow House Captain

entries: House captains will do anything to protect their family—whether that's their birth house or their platoon of scrappy rebels. I'd do anything for my (sometimes infuriating) mother and for my chosen family, so I admire their dedication.

A drow house captain leads the troops of an Underdark faction, whether defending a stronghold or leading forces against enemies. These officers make extensive study of strategy and tactics to become effective leaders in battle.

Among Lolth's devotees in the city of Menzoberranzan in the Forgotten Realms, each noble house entrusts the leadership of its military forces to a house captain, who is typically the first or second son of a drow matron mother. Elsewhere drow house captains fight in the war against Lolth, often allying with duergar and others who also wish to rid their subterranean world of that god's malevolence.

monsterFluff.name: Drow Inquisitor
entries: Lolth's worshipers expect treachery—the Spider Queen encourages it, after all. A certain amount of backstabbing and double-crossing can be managed, but too much can undermine an entire community. To keep some semblance of order and to root out traitors, priestesses of Lolth employ inquisitors. Inquisitors are chosen from the ranks of the priesthood, and their authority is equaled only by that of the {@creature drow matron mother|MPMM|drow matron mothers} (also in this book) of the noble houses. Anyone they decide is at odds with the hierarchy faces painful interrogation and usually an excruciating death.

monsterFluff.name: Drow Matron Mother
entries: Among drow followers of {@deity Lolth|Drow|MTF}, each noble house is led by a matron mother, an influential priestess of Lolth charged with carrying out the god's will while also advancing the interests of the family. Matron mothers embody the scheming and treachery associated with the Queen of Spiders. Each stands at the center of a vast conspiratorial web, with demons, spiders, and conscripted soldiers positioned between them and their enemies. Although matron mothers command great power, that power depends on maintaining the Spider Queen's favor, and the goddess sometimes capriciously takes back what she has given. The stat block here represents a matron mother at the height of her power.

A matron mother is almost never encountered alone. She is typically accompanied by a {@creature drow favored consort|MPMM} and a {@creature drow house captain|MPMM}, each of whom appears in this book. Other Underdark creatures might also be in the priestess's presence, providing protection or advice.

entries.name: Mothers of Rebellion
entries: Some matron mothers renounce {@deity Lolth|Drow|MTF} and join the war against their former goddess. Such drow could be of any alignment, and they lose the following abilities in the stat block: Lolth's Fickle Favor, Summon Servant, and Compel Demon. Even without these abilities, drow matron mothers are formidable opponents, and several of them hold positions of great influence in the Underdark armies arrayed against the followers of Lolth.

entries.name: A Matron Mother's Lair
entries: The palace of a drow matron mother is her home and fortress. Sigils throughout the building allow the matron mother to use the following lair actions while within it.

Any temple of {@deity Lolth|Drow|MTF} also functions as a matron mother's lair while she is inside it, unless she has renounced Lolth or another matron mother is present. When two or more matron mothers gather within a temple of their goddess, none of them can use it as their lair.

monsterFluff.name: Drow Shadowblade
entries: Drow shadowblades steal down the dim passages of the Underdark, bound on errands of mayhem. They protect enclaves and Underdark cities from enemies and track down thieves who make off with prized treasures. In the city of Menzoberranzan in the Forgotten Realms, noble houses often employ shadowblades to eliminate rivals from other houses. In communities free of Lolth's sway, they serve as spies tasked with foiling the plots of that demon lord's cult. In any role they take on, they move undetected until the moment they attack—and then they are the last thing their victims see.
A shadowblade gains their powers over shadow via a ritual in which they kill a shadow demon and mystically prevent it from re-forming in the Abyss, siphoning its essence into themselves.

entries.name: Duergar

entries: Duergar architecture is remarkable for its brutalist grandeur. It is not a style I would use for my towers—I prefer gold, gems, and tracery—but I admire the boldness of dwarven stonework.
The mental power that duergar wield was given to them by illithids. But why would illithids create servants who could turn invisible or grow to ogre size?
Most likely because those servants would excel at herding their masters' other minions. In retrospect, it seems arguable that duergar escaped bondage because their jailers had given them the keys.

Duergar are dwarves of the deep reaches of the Underdark and other sunless realms. Their personalities and abilities have been deeply impacted by their ancestors' captivity and torment by mind flayers; they were infused with powerful psionic abilities but also a profound gloom. In some, this strain of sorrow inspires works of grand but melancholic beauty, while in others, it manifests as rage.

Like many who dwell in the Underdark, duergar must constantly be on guard against the raids and plots of their neighbors. To this end, duergar warriors fulfill a variety of combat roles, often marrying their fury in battle with their psionic abilities or training dangerous Underdark creatures as mounts.

Denigrated by some as joyless, duergar are in fact deeply passionate in all that they do—even if that passion rarely manifests as mirth. They bring an emotional intensity to their lives, whether they're exploring neighboring tunnels, defending their homes, engaging with their families, or crafting bold new works. The bonds of friendship and kinship are strong, though navigating the inevitable outbursts of frustration and despair is not always easy. Similarly, duergar tend to be very community-minded—in the Underdark, all must cooperate to survive.

Among the duergar of the Forgotten Realms, creation is a fiercely passionate process. They tend to favor works that are sturdy and grand, but in a bare, stripped-down fashion that favors geometric forms. The strongholds they design are blocky and stark, and the weapons they forge are blatantly tools of violence. While others may decry their creations as cold and bare of ornamentation to the point of austerity, duergar see them as honoring the materials used and honest about their purpose.

entries.name: Duergar Constructs
entries: Creative duergar engineers have built numerous war machines, including some that can be fused with a duergar. Such a duergar-machine hybrid is fueled by the duergar's psionic energy, and the duergar inside the machine can psychically channel pain into power when attacked.

These machines are deployed to assist with construction projects and war. Some duergar bravely volunteer to become hybrids, while other duergar are forced into the fusion by Underdark tyrants. Unless incapacitated, the duergar inside a machine can extricate themself from it over the course of a short rest, completing the process at the rest's end.
Duergar despots replace parts of their bodies with mechanical devices that they control through their psionic abilities.
The duergar hammerer is a digging machine and siege engine, used to dig tunnels and besiege enemy fortifications.
Kavalrachni are duergar cavalry trained to fight while riding {@creature female steeder|MPMM|female steeders} (in this book) or other Underdark creatures as mounts.

Wearing fearsome masks, duergar mind masters usually operate as spies, both inside and beyond a duergar stronghold. Their psionically augmented abilities enable them to see through illusions with ease and shrink down to miniature size to spy on their targets.
A duergar screamer uses sonic energy to grind rock into dust and to hurl invaders to the ground.
Soulblades are duergar combatants whose mastery of psionics allows them to manifest blades of psychic energy to slice apart their foes.
Stone guards are elite troops deployed in small numbers to bolster war bands of regulars or organized into elite strike forces for specific missions.
A warlord is cunning, inspiring, and merciless in equal parts. A skilled leader in battle, the warlord can use spikes of psionic energy to compel the warriors they command to fight harder.
Xarrorn are specialists who construct weapons using a mixture of alchemy and psionics.

monsterFluff.name: Dybbuk
entries: Dybbuks are demons that terrorize mortals on the Material Plane by possessing corpses and giving them a semblance of life, after which the demons use them to engage in a range of sordid activities.

In their natural form, dybbuks appear as translucent flying jellyfish, trailing long tentacles as they move through the air. They rarely travel in this fashion, however. Instead, a dybbuk possesses a suitable corpse as a vehicle, rousing the body from death. Dybbuks delight in terrorizing other creatures by making their host bodies behave in horrifying ways—throwing up gouts of blood, excreting piles of squirming maggots, and contorting their limbs in impossible ways as they scuttle across the ground.

monsterFluff.name: Eidolon
entries: To protect sites they deem holy, gods often rely on eidolons, ghostly spirits bound to safeguard a sacred place. Forged from the souls of those with unwavering devotion, eidolons stalk temples and vaults to ensure that no enemy defiles, damages, or plunders these sites. If an enemy sets foot inside a warded location, the {@creature eidolon|MPMM} plunges into a {@creature sacred statue|MPMM|statue} specially prepared to house its soul; it then animates this effigy and uses the statue to drive out the intruders.

entries.name: Eladrin

entries: If an autumn eladrin invites you over for dinner, come with an empty stomach. Their goodwill extends to heaping portions.
Note to self: send some of my spring eladrin friends to visit Mordenkainen. That'll teach him to lighten up.

Eladrin dwell in the verdant splendor of the Feywild. They are related to the elves found on the Material Plane. But while other elves can temper their wild impulses, eladrin are ruled by emotion—and due to their magical nature, they undergo physical changes to match their changes in temperament.

Eladrin have spent centuries in the Feywild, and most of them have become Fey creatures as a result—those presented here are of the Fey variety. Some are still Humanoid, however, similar in that respect to their other elven kin.

The magic flowing through eladrin responds to their emotional state by transforming them into different seasonal aspects, with behaviors and abilities that change with their forms. Some eladrin might remain in a particular aspect for years, while others run through the emotional spectrum each week.

entries.name: Changeable Natures
entries: Whenever one of the eladrin presented here finishes a long rest, they can associate themself with a different season, provided they aren't {@condition incapacitated}. When the eladrin makes this change, they use the stat block of the new season rather than their old stat block. Any damage the eladrin sustained in their previous form applies to the new form, as do any conditions or other ongoing effects affecting them.

monsterFluff.name: Elder Brain
entries: The ultimate expression of mind flayer domination, an elder brain sprawls within a vat of viscous brine, cared for by mind flayer minions as it touches the thoughts of creatures near and far. It scrawls upon the canvas of the creatures' minds, rewriting their thoughts and authoring their dreams.

An elder brain sustains itself by consuming the brains of other creatures. If its mind flayer servants don't bring meals directly to it, the elder brain reaches out with tendrils of thought, compelling creatures to come to it so that it can feed on them.

When a mind flayer perishes, the elder brain's servants feed its brain to their master, which then absorbs the knowledge and experience contained therein. Mind flayers conceive of this oneness with the elder brain as a sacred state akin to an afterlife.

entries.name: Hive Mind
entries: Elder brains are so-called among non-illithids because they act as the central communication hub for an entire mind flayer colony, just as a brain does for a living body. Linked to the elder brain, the colony acts like a single organism, acting in concert as if each illithid were the digit of a hand.

An elder brain considers itself and its desires the most important things in the multiverse, and the mind flayers in its colony nothing more than extensions of its will. Each presides over its colony according to its own unique personality and storehouse of collected knowledge and experience. Some elder brains reign as tyrants, while others serve as sages, counselors, and repositories of information and lore for the mind flayers that protect and nourish them.

entries.name: An Elder Brain's Lair
entries: The lair of an elder brain lies deep in the heart of a mind flayer colony. The brain dwells in a dimly glowing brine pool filled with brackish water infused with its vital fluids and psionic energy.

An elder brain's ambitions are always tempered by its relative immobility. Although its telepathic senses can reach for miles, moving anywhere is always a dangerous proposition. If forced outside its brine pool, an elder brain swiftly expires, and transporting an elder brain in its pool through confining and tortuous subterranean tunnels frequently proves difficult or impossible.

Older oblexes, called adults and elders, have eaten so many memories that they can form duplicates of the creatures they have devoured from the substance of their bodies, sending these copies off to lure prey into their clutches while remaining tethered to the slime by long tendrils of goo. These duplicated creatures are indistinguishable from their victims except for a faint sulfurous smell. Oblexes use these duplicates to lead prey into danger or to infiltrate settlements so they can feed on superior victims.

monsterFluff.name: Elder Tempest
entries: Terrifying storms manifest in the bodies of elder tempests. Beings carved from clouds, wind, rain, and lightning, elder tempests assume the shape of serpents that slither through the sky. They drown the land beneath them with rain and stab the earth with lances of lightning. Punishing winds scream around them as they fly, feeding the chaos they create.

entries.name: Elemental Myrmidons
entries: Elemental myrmidons are Elementals conjured and bound by magic into ritually created suits of plate armor. In this form, they possess no recollection of their former existence as free Elementals. They exist only to follow the commands of their creators.
Enchanters know how to magically influence minds. Benign enchanters use this magic to defuse violence and sow peace, while malevolent enchanters are some of the most evil of all spellcasters.
Evokers harness arcane energy to destroy. Many armies employ evokers to rain destruction down on enemy forces.

monsterFluff.name: Fire Giant Dreadnought

entries: When I first saw a fire giant dreadnought, I doubted the giant could even move. I quickly learned my error.
Most fire giants value not just strength but also skill at forgecraft. The foundry is the heart of any fire giant community. It is a temple, school, proving ground, and political hub rolled into one.

Those whose primary virtue is brawn are usually consigned to the lowliest of tasks, such as working forge bellows or moving coal. However, the strongest among these can excel at and gain rank through a specialized role: the dreadnought.

Dreadnoughts are massively powerful fire giants who wield two huge shields like plow blades. These shields bear spikes on their exterior and have hollow interiors into which the dreadnought pours hot coals at the first sign of danger. Armed with these two shields, the dreadnought can present a fiery wall to any attacker. When the dreadnought has finished, often all that is left of a foe is a smoking smear on the floor.

When not called on to fight, dreadnoughts maintain their strength by using their shields to shove huge quantities of coal, stone, or ore about the foundry. Occasionally, dreadnoughts are called on by their superiors to accompany a war or diplomatic delegation and use their fierce and intimidating demeanor to strengthen the delegation's position.

Firenewts who serve Imix, Prince of Evil Fire, live in militaristic theocracies that revere elemental fire in its most destructive incarnation and promote aggression and cruelty. Firenewt warlocks of Imix lead these theocracies or serve as advisors to a high priest.

A firenewt warrior can spew fire. Many of these warriors have a close relationship with giant striders (in this book). They provide shelter, food, and breeding grounds in their lairs for giant striders, which then voluntarily serve them as mounts.

entries.name: Firenewts
entries: Originally from the Elemental Plane of Fire, firenewts can be found on the Material Plane near hot springs and volcanoes. These amphibians need hot water to live, becoming sluggish after spending a week away from a source of moist heat. Firenewts therefore delve for sources of heat in the earth, and a firenewt lair features a network of channels and sluices to circulate hot liquid through the area.

monsterFluff.name: Flail Snail
entries: A flail snail is a creature of elemental earth that is prized for its multihued shell. It may seem harmless, but if a creature big enough to be a threat approaches too close, the snail flashes a scintillating light and attacks with its mace-like tentacles.

Left undisturbed, a flail snail moves slowly along the ground. It consumes everything on the surface, including rocks, sand, and soil, and it stops periodically to relish crystal growths and other large mineral deposits. It leaves behind a shimmering trail that quickly solidifies into a thin and nearly transparent layer. This glassy residue can be harvested and cut to form window panes. It can also be heated and spun into other glass objects. Some folk make a living from trailing flail snails to collect this glass.

entries.name: Using the Shell of a Flail Snail
entries: A flail snail shell weighs about 250 pounds and has numerous uses. An intact shell can sell for 5,000 gp.

Many hunters seek the shell for its antimagic properties. A skilled armorer can make three shields from one shell. For 1 month, each shield gives its wielder the snail's Antimagic Shell trait. When the shield's magic fades, it becomes an exotic shield that is the perfect item from which to make a {@item spellguard shield}.

A flail snail shell can also be used to make a {@item robe of scintillating colors}. The shell is ground and added to the dye applied to the fabric. The powder is also a material component of the ritual that enchants the robe.

monsterFluff.name: Flind
entries: When the demon lord Yeenoghu wants to create a particularly fearsome war band leader, he transforms an excep tionally strong and vicious gnoll into a demonic warrior known as a flind.

A war band of demon-worshiping gnolls typically contains only one flind, and that creature sets the war band's path. Because of its special connection to Yeenoghu, a flind uses demonic insight to guide the gnolls toward weak prey ripe for slaughter.
Unlike other leaders who might skulk behind their minions, a flind leads the charge in battle. Its flail causes wracking pain, paralysis, and disorientation in those it strikes.

monsterFluff.name: Fraz-Urb'luu
entries: Fraz-Urb'luu is the Prince of {@skill Deception} and Demon Lord of Illusions. He uses every trick, every ounce of demonic cunning, to manipulate his enemies—mortal and Fiend alike—to do his will. Fraz-Urb'luu can create dreamlands and mind-bending fantasies able to deceive the most discerning foes.

Once imprisoned for centuries below Castle Greyhawk on the world of Oerth, Fraz-Urb'luu has slowly rebuilt his power in the Abyss. He seeks the pieces of the legendary {@item staff of power} taken from him by those who imprisoned him and commands his servants to do likewise.

The Prince of {@skill Deception}'s true form is like that of a great gargoyle, some 12 feet tall, with an extended, muscular neck; a smiling face framed by long, pointed ears and lank, dark hair; and bat-like wings are furled against his powerful shoulders. He can assume other forms, however, from the hideous to the beautiful.

Many of the cultists of Fraz-Urb'luu aren't even aware they serve the Prince of {@skill Deception}, believing their master is a beneficent being and granter of wishes, some lost god or Celestial, or even another Fiend. Fraz-Urb'luu wears all these masks and more. He particularly delights in aiding demon-hunters against his demonic adversaries, driving the hunters to greater and greater atrocities in the name of their cause, only to eventually reveal his true nature and claim their souls as his own.

entries.name: Cultists of Fraz-Urb'luu
entries: {@note See the {@cult Cult of Fraz-Urb'luu|MPMM} entry.}

entries.name: Fraz-Urb'luu's Lair
entries: Fraz-Urb'luu's lair lies within the abyssal realm of Hollow's Heart, a plain of white dust with few structures on it. The lair itself is the city of Zoragmelok, a circular fortress surrounded by adamantine walls topped with razors and hooks. Corkscrew towers loom above twisted domes and vast amphitheaters, forming a surreal and disorienting cityscape.
The challenge rating of Fraz-Urb'luu is 24 (62,000 XP) when he's encountered in his lair.

monsterFluff.name: Froghemoth
entries: A froghemoth is an amphibious predator as big as an elephant. It lairs in swamps and has four tentacles, a thick rubbery hide, a fang-filled maw with a prehensile tongue, and an extendable stalk sporting three bulbous eyes that face in different directions.

Froghemoths are creatures not of this world. A journal purportedly written long ago by the wizard Lum describes strange, cylindrical chambers of metal buried in the ground from which froghemoths emerged, but no reliable reports of the location of such places exist.

Every few years, a froghemoth can lay a fertile egg without mating. The froghemoth cares nothing for its egg and might eat the hatchling. A young froghemoth's survival thus depends on its parent leaving it behind in indifference. A newborn froghemoth grows to full size over a period of months by indiscriminately preying on other creatures in its swampy domain. It learns to hide its enormous body in murky pools, keeping only its eyestalk above water to watch for passing creatures. When food comes within reach, the froghemoth erupts from its pool, tentacles and tongue flailing. It can grab several targets at once; it wraps its tongue around one and pulls it in to be devoured while holding the rest at bay.

If {@creature bullywug||bullywugs} come across a froghemoth, the bullywugs may treat the froghemoth as a god and do all they can to coax the monster into their den. A froghemoth can be tamed (after a fashion) by offering it food, and bullywugs can communicate with it on a basic level, so the creature might eat only a few bullywugs before following the rest. The bullywugs gather food as tribute for it, provide it with a comfortable lair, protect it from harm, and try to ensure that any of its offspring reach maturity.

monsterFluff.name: Frost Giant Everlasting One
entries: To hold its place or rise within the ordning, a frost giant must routinely face mighty foes in single combat. Some seek out magic that will aid them, but enchanted objects can be taken or lost. True greatness relies on personal prowess. Faced with this truth, a frost giant might seek a supernatural gift from Vaprak the Destroyer.

Vaprak is a ferocious god of strength and hunger also worshiped by some ogres and trolls. He likes to tempt frost giants with dreams of glory followed by nightmares of bloody cannibalism. Those who don't shrink from such visions or report them to priests of Thrym receive more of the same. If a frost giant comes to relish these dreams and nightmares, as some do, Vaprak sets a troll upon a sacred quest to find the frost giant and meet the giant in secret. The troll offers up its own body to be devoured in Vaprak's name. Only the boldest and most determined frost giants can finish such a gory feast.

After devouring the troll sent by Vaprak, bones and all, a frost giant becomes an everlasting one, gaining tremendous strength, an ill temper, and a troll's regenerative ability. With these gifts, the frost giant can swiftly claim the title of jarl and easily fend off rivals for decades. However, if the frost giant doesn't give enough honor to Vaprak or fails to heed Vaprak's visions, injuries the frost giant sustains heal wrong, resulting in discolored skin; warty scars; and vestigial body parts, such as extra digits, limbs, and even heads. The touch of Vaprak can no longer be hidden then, and the everlasting one is either killed or exiled by their clan. Sometimes small communities of everlasting ones gather and even reproduce, passing the "blessing" and worship of Vaprak from one generation to the next.

monsterFluff.name: Frost Salamander
entries: Frost salamanders are natives of the Plane of Ice, also called the Frostfell, which rests between the Plane of Air and the Plane of Water. Frost salamanders especially like to hunt warm-blooded creatures. They sometimes travel to frigid climes on the Material Plane by wandering through planar gates.

Frost salamanders' aggressive appetite for any heat source leads them to attack expeditions and settlements that other predators would avoid, as they often mistake the fire of a forge or a campfire for a large, tasty meal. {@creature Azer||Azers} use this predilection to hunt frost salamanders. Venturing into the Frostfell, they use large fires to lure these creatures into traps, then kill them and collect their hides and fangs for use in crafting weapons and armor.

Although frost salamanders can burrow their way through loose soil, they prefer to dig into ice. They roll around in piles of broken chunks of ice, allowing it to scratch their backs as they grind it down. This habit leads them to create extensive networks of ice caves, which become ever larger as they claw fresh chunks of ice from the walls of their lairs.

A frost salamander that dwells in a lair for a while carves out enough space to allow a small army to camp within. Inexperienced travelers who come across these caves see them as a welcome shelter, though they are anything but. Frost salamanders greedily devour any prey foolhardy enough to try sleeping in their lairs.
On rare occasions, {@creature frost giant||frost giants} capture and tame these creatures, using them to burrow into the ice to help create outposts and fortresses.

monsterFluff.name: Gauth
entries: A gauth is a hungry, tyrannical creature similar to a beholder that eats magic and tries to exact tribute from anything weaker than itself. Its body is about 4 feet in diameter, with six eyestalks, a central eye (sometimes surrounded by multiple smaller eyes), and four small grasping tentacles near its mouth. It has color and texture variations similar to a true beholder.

A gauth can survive on meat but prefers to sustain itself with power drained from magic objects. If starved of magic for several weeks, it is forced back to its home plane, so it constantly seeks new items to drain. A gauth might employ creatures to bring it items that can provide it with sustenance.

When the ritual to summon a spectator goes wrong, a gauth might push itself through the flawed connection, arriving immediately or several minutes later. It might present itself as a beholder to ignorant creatures in an attempt to intimidate them, or as a spectator to its summoner in order to drain magic items it is expected to guard.

A {@creature beholder} usually drives away or kills any gauths that enter its territory, but it might choose to force them to serve it as lieutenants. Gauths are less xenophobic than beholders, so they might form small clusters and work together, though they're just as likely to ignore each other entirely.

monsterFluff.name: Gazer
entries: A gazer is a tiny manifestation of the dreams of a beholder. It resembles the beholder who dreamed it into existence, but its body is only 8 inches wide and it has only four eyestalks. It follows its creator like a devoted, aggressive puppy, and sometimes small packs of these creatures patrol their master's lair for vermin to kill and lone creatures to harass.

A gazer can't speak any languages but can approximate words and sentences it hears, mimicking them in a high-pitched, mocking manner. Beholders find gazers amusing and tolerate their presence like spoiled pets. Some beholders with wizard minions insist they take a gazer as a familiar because the beholders can see through the eyes of these creatures.

A wild gazer (one living separately from a beholder) is territorial, eats bugs and little animals, and is known for playing with its food. A lone wild gazer avoids picking fights with creatures that are Medium or larger, but a pack of them might take on larger prey. A gazer might follow the folk in its territory, noisily mimicking their speech and generally being a nuisance, until they leave the area, but it flees if confronted by something it can't kill.

monsterFluff.name: Geryon
entries: Geryon is locked in an endless struggle with Levistus for control of Stygia. The two have fought for centuries, each displacing the other innumerable times. Currently, Levistus claims lordship over Stygia, but he has been trapped in an enormous block of ice at the command of Asmodeus. In response, Geryon is marshaling his followers, hoping to use this opportunity to replace his hated rival.

Among the archdevils, Geryon is known for his martial prowess. He is a ferocious hunter and a relentless tracker. He often joins his troops in battle; he loves to feel flesh and steel sundered beneath his claws and to taste his foes' blood.
